title: Hugo Maradona
text:
Hugo Hernán Maradona (9 May 1969 – 28 December 2021), also known as El Turco, was an Argentine <a href="association%20football">football</a> player and coach. He was the younger brother of <a href="Diego%20Maradona">Diego Maradona</a>. He played as a <a href="midfielder">midfielder</a> for clubs in South America, Europe, Japan, and Canada, and was a member of the <a href="Argentina%20national%20under-17%20football%20team">Argentina U-16 national team</a>.
Career.
In 1985, Maradona was a part of the <a href="Argentina%20national%20under-17%20football%20team">Argentina U-16 national team</a>'s squad that competed at the U16 <a href="1985%20FIFA%20U-16%20World%20Championship">South American</a> and <a href="1985%20South%20American%20U-16%20Championship">World Championship</a>s in China. In Argentina's first round match against <a href="Congo%20national%20football%20team">Congo</a>, he scored two goals to help the team to a 4–2 win, which however was one goal short of what Argentina needed to advance past the group stage.
During 1987, Hugo Maradona was bought by <a href="Ascoli%20Calcio">Ascoli</a> to play in the Italian Serie A championship. He played just 13 matches without scoring a <a href="Goal%20%28sport%29">goal</a>, and was sold at the end of the season to <a href="Rayo%20Vallecano">Rayo Vallecano</a> in Spain. During 1989 he moved again, that time to <a href="SK%20Rapid%20Wien">Rapid Wien</a>, and after that experience he went back to Argentina. 
In 1992, he moved to Japan to play for <a href="Tosu%20Futures">PJM Futures</a> (renamed as Tosu Futures after changing their hometown in 1994), which was aiming to promote to inaugurated <a href="J.%20League">J. League</a>. After playing for Futures for three seasons, he played for <a href="Avispa%20Fukuoka">Fukuoka Blux(renamed as Avispa Fukuoka after their promotion to J. League in 1996)</a> in 1995 and 1996 seasons, and <a href="Consadole%20Sapporo">Consadole Sapporo</a> in 1997 and 1998 seasons. He played in the <a href="J1%20League">J1 League</a> in 1996 and 1998.
After retiring from association football as a player, Maradona lived a relatively quiet life in Argentina.
In 2004, Hugo Maradona moved part-time to Puerto Rico, where he became part of that country's association football federation's attempt to invigorate the sport among Puerto Ricans by becoming the head coach of the <a href="Puerto%20Rico%20Islanders">Puerto Rico Islanders</a>, a team in the American <a href="USL%20First%20Division">USL First Division</a>. He then moved back to Italy, working for a number of youth and amateur teams in the <a href="Naples">Naples</a> region.
Personal life and death.
Maradona was born in <a href="Lan%C3%BAs">Lanús</a> on 9 May 1969, as the youngest sibling of brothers <a href="Diego%20Maradona">Diego Maradona</a> and <a href="Ra%C3%BAl%20Maradona">Raúl Maradona</a>, both noted footballers in their own right. His father Diego Maradona "Chitoro" (1927–2015), who worked at a chemicals factory, was of <a href="Guaran%C3%AD%20people">Guaraní</a> (Indigenous) and <a href="Galician%20Argentines">Galician</a> (<a href="Spanish%20Argentines">Spanish</a>) descent, and his mother Dalma Salvadora Franco, "Doña Tota" (1930–2011), was of <a href="Italian%20Argentines">Italian</a> descent.
He died from a heart attack at his home in <a href="Monte%20di%20Procida">Monte di Procida</a>, near <a href="Naples">Naples</a>, on 28 December 2021, at the age of 52.
